Top-3 Scripts:
ul_605457: journalctl -b

journalctl -f -u rc-local.service

journalctl -f $(which python)

Explanations about Options.-f:
Show only the most recent journal entries, and continuously print new entries as they
 are appended to the journal.

Top-3 Similar Questions: au_186140: Cannot see boot options after editing grub background
au_40471: Where can I find the log files for mounting disks?
Top-3 Scripts: au_186140: sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt && sudo mount --bind /dev /mnt/dev && sudo mount --bind /proc /mnt/proc && sudo mount --bind /sys /mnt/sys && sudo mount --bind /dev/pts /mnt/dev/pts && sudo chroot /mnt

Explanations about Options.-l:
Add the labels in the mount output. mount must have permission to read the disk
 device (e.g. be set-user-ID root) for this to work. One can set such a label for
 ext2, ext3 or ext4 using the e2label(8) utility, or for XFS using xfs_admin(8), or
 for reiserfs using reiserfstune(8).
Explanations about Options.--bind:
Remount a subtree somewhere else (so that its contents are available in both
 places). See above, under Bind mounts.
Explanations about Options.-R:
Remount a subtree and all possible submounts somewhere else (so that its contents
 are available in both places). See above, the subsection Bind mounts.
